original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Dreams can show you ideas about things you didn't know you were thinking about. Many people have dreams about flying, falling, losing teeth, or having no clothes in public. These dreams can mean the same thing for many people. To know what they mean for you, think about what happens in your life and how you feel every day.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: One of the most interesting things about wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs in Moscow. In Moscow, there are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some dogs were born in the wild, and some used to have owners who left them. Some dogs live alone, and some live in groups. In 2010, scientists looked at the dogs and saw that they adapted well to life in the city. The dogs learned it is safer to cross the street with people, and some even seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. simplified: Wonder is the first book by RJ Palacio, who is from New York. She got the idea for the book after she saw a girl on the street with a different-looking face. Wonder is very popular in the United States and has won many awards. Many schools use it to talk about bullying, friendship, and being different. A movie of Wonder is being made, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio will write next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. simplified: Chloe has two pet rats named Zena and Roxy. She understands why people don't like rats because she didn't like them either. But then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats, and Chloe saw that they were friendly and smart. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she wanted to have two of them.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town is not always safe for baboons. Some baboons have been hurt or died in car accidents. Others have been shocked when they touched electric cables. Baboons are a type of animal that needs protection. To help them, the city has hired people called Baboon Monitors. Their job is to keep baboons away from the city. They chase them back to the wild. This plan works sometimes, but baboons come back to the city because it is easy to find food there.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. simplified: I work for a big IT company, but their main office is in the United States. I do all my work online from my home. This means I don't spend time traveling to work or talking too much with other workers. I work on different projects, and this is very good for me. It means I can take time off easily if I need to go to my children's school shows or go to the dentist. The problem is that because I don't have set office hours, I often work late into the evening and sometimes miss dinner to finish my work.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: Every day, people see many ads on social media, in magazines, and in shops. These ads show things to buy. In the UK, people are buying more clothes and shoes than before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy things quickly. Big stores sell clothes so cheaply that people wear them only a few times and then throw them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the sun and saw dust rising from a car driving towards the Big House. The horses moved their tails to get rid of flies and did not care that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came here when he had to, and Sam liked that. The less he saw his boss, the longer he would have a job. Mr. Carter wiped sweat from his neck, and his shirt had wet spots like on a map. His skin was getting red because of the June sun, but he looked like a man who usually stayed inside while others worked outside.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: Many people who live in Berlin, Germany said that shooting pigs was too cruel. There were many arguments between those who hunt and those who love animals. Because of these complaints, the city government chose a kinder way to deal with pigs. They decided not to shoot pigs. Instead, they put up fences and made a rule that people cannot feed pigs. We do not know yet if this plan will work. Warmer winters mean there are more pigs now than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
simplified: Suzanne wrote the Hunger Games book and was inspired by Greek myths. When she was young, she liked the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens is controlled by Crete. The people of Athens do not like this. So, as a punishment, the king of Crete, Minos, makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. These children are put into a maze, and a monster called the Minotaur eats them. But one boy named Theseus fights and kills the Minotaur. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen is like a new Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos bring people and animals together. They can teach people about saving animals and the places they live in. Some zoos are safe places for animals that were treated badly in circuses or left by their owners. Zoos also study how animals act and how to help them when they are sick.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified: A new idea called the 'buy nothing' trend is becoming popular. It started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the US. This idea is against spending too much money and buying too many things during Black Friday and Cyber Monday, which are part of the Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people hold protests and destroy their credit cards. During the year, groups meet to trade and fix things they already have.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
simplified: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on what you think. In many countries, writing or painting on things that are not yours is seen as vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police, and some have had to pay money as punishment. Many city councils say that cleaning graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains is very expensive.

original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.
simplified: What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more people are starting to see it as a real type of art. There have been big shows of street art in galleries in cities like Paris, London, and Los Angeles. An American artist named Elura Emerald set up a street art show in a New York gallery in 2008. She said street artists are just sharing their thoughts and are not doing anything bad. They should be liked and celebrated.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. This means they have about 2,000 dreams every year. So, when someone is 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams. We forget most of our dreams, but we still remember a few thousand of them in our lives. It's not hard to believe that sometimes a dream seems to match something that happens in real life, especially if the dream is about something common.

original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.
simplified: The Hunger Games is set in the future, after North America is gone. There is a country called Panem, which has twelve poor districts. The rich Capitol controls everything in Panem. Each district must make different products for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, gives all the coal to the country. There was a thirteenth district, but it fought against the Capitol and was destroyed.

original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! simplified: Wild animals sometimes come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons are coming to live near people's houses. Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pets, so many people in the city do not like having them around.

original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.
simplified: Many bridge accidents happen when the bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because the engineers make a mistake, like a wrong calculation. The bridge can fall down because it is too heavy, and this can be very dangerous for the workers on it.

original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.
simplified: George Lucas is a film director who used the hero's journey idea in his movies. In this story, the hero starts with a normal life. Then, something important happens, and the hero goes on an adventure that changes everything. In Star Wars, Luke has a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. One day, he finds a message from Princess Leia inside the robot R2D2. This message is the 'call to adventure' that begins Luke's exciting journey.

original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
simplified: One way to stop an asteroid from hitting Earth is to use a nuclear bomb to blow it up. This idea is like a story from a movie, and it was in a 1998 movie called Armageddon. But NASA has a real plan named HAMMER. They want to send very big rockets to an asteroid that is coming toward Earth. These rockets will try to change the asteroid's direction. If the asteroid gets too close, the rockets will have bombs to destroy it.

original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
simplified: According to Campbell, the hero at first does not want to go on an adventure. But then, a teacher comes to help them and they choose to start the adventure by entering a 'special world'. In this special world, the hero must pass tests, fight enemies, and make friends before they can face their biggest challenge. For Luke, the teacher is Obi-Wan. His friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. The enemy is Darth Vader on the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
simplified: Some things that people do not use much might seem useless, but they can be useful for others. Because of the internet, people have found ways to make money by sharing things they do not use a lot. Websites and social media groups help people buy and sell used items. It is now very easy for people to share things with each other. This is called the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: In the 18th and 19th centuries, people had two main ideas about dreams. One idea was that dreams show us things we don't know we are thinking. Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can know our hidden feelings and problems. The other idea was different. It said dreams are just random thoughts in the brain. These happen when the brain is organizing what happened during the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these random images and feelings and make them into a story.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.
simplified: I work for myself as a freelancer. This is good because I decide what to do and how to use my time. At first, I worked from home, but it was difficult to focus. There were many things that took my attention, like house chores, making another cup of tea, and my family asking for my help. So, I went to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi was not very good, and I drank too much coffee. Finally, I chose to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers. I liked getting ready to go to work in the morning and focusing better in an office-like place.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.
simplified: NASA wants to find some middle-sized near-Earth objects, or NEOs. To do this, they need money to build a special space telescope called NEOCam. This telescope will help find asteroids by using infrared light. If NASA gets the money, they think they can find these NEOs in ten years. After finding them, they still need to figure out how to stop really dangerous asteroids from hitting Earth. These dangerous asteroids are called PHAs.

original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. simplified: The 'buy nothing' trend is popular with people on social media. Usually, they show clothes and makeup for people to buy. Now, some YouTube stars tell people not to buy anything. Some people do this for a whole year. Two friends in Canada worked for a year to only buy food. For the first three months, they learned to live without buying things like electronics, clothes, or items for the house. Later, they stopped using services like haircuts, eating at restaurants, or buying petrol for their cars. After one year, they saved $55,000.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.
simplified: Pi thinks religion is very important. His family is Hindu, but Pi wants to learn about other religions too. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Everyone is surprised when Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim, and Christian all at the same time. His family and teachers tell him to pick one religion, but Pi says, 'I just want to love God.' After that, they let him choose for himself.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
simplified: Some people believe that writing your dreams down can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you are dreaming, and you can choose what happens in the dream. For example, you can change a scary dream into a nice one, or you can decide what happens in the dream like a movie director. This way, instead of just trying to understand what your dreams mean, you can make them. But, you might also want to keep some dreams that let your mind show you your true thoughts.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
simplified: People might not know they are part of the problem with clothes that are used once and thrown away. This is because they give their old clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all the clothes they get. 'Fast fashion' means clothes go out of style quickly and are often not good enough to reuse. People do not want to buy them second-hand. A lot of these clothes end up in the trash. Also, many clothes that charities can't sell are sent to other countries, which causes more economic and environmental problems.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
simplified: Some people love adventure and try many challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of them. She has climbed the tallest mountain on each continent. She also rode a bike across Canada and ran a long race in the Sahara Desert where it was 45ºC. But maybe her most amazing trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and needed help. Many would stop after that, but Meagan continued. She got to the South Pole forty days later. She pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food through very cold weather and ice storms.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
simplified: Blek le Rat started by painting rats on the walls in Paris, his home. Now, he wants people to think about social problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities so that people think about homelessness.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.
simplified: In some places, city leaders want artists to stop painting graffiti everywhere. They let artists paint in special places. In Taiwan, these are called 'graffiti zones,' where artists can paint on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city lets some artists paint on train cars.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints big, colorful pictures of people and animals. She likes to paint in different places. You can find her art on sidewalks, in empty factories, and on abandoned cars. Faith47 likes that street art does not stay forever. It can be washed away by rain or removed by city cleaners. To her, this shows that life always changes. Things end, and new things begin.

original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.
simplified: In her old job, Gabriela worked where people respected bosses a lot. Bosses made big choices, and people did not ask many questions. But her new Swedish team worked differently. In Sweden, bosses and workers make decisions together. Bosses act like teachers. They want people to think for themselves and ask questions.

original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. simplified: When Gabriela understood that she was different from her team, she decided to talk to them about how they felt about her leading them. The team was happy because she wanted their opinion. original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: People have been drawing and writing on walls for many years. A long time ago, people in Africa and Europe made pictures of animals and people in caves. original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
simplified: I think it is interesting to think about how we can change and improve as humans by adding things to our bodies. Imagine if we could put a computer inside our brain! Soon, we will be able to do this and become better at math, seeing and hearing things, and remembering. This idea will become more and more normal.

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified: The talk was very interesting, and the speaker understood some important things. For example, parents influence their children a lot. We cannot expect teenagers to stop texting during homework if they see their parents using social media while cooking or when stopped at a red light. The speaker also said that people want to be in many places at the same time. So, they switch between talking in person and talking online. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They meet but stay quiet while they talk online with other people.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified: News stories sometimes make us think that the world is more violent now, but there is some good news. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 big wars that killed more than 100,000 people each. Today, there are still wars, but countries usually live together more peacefully than before. However, terrorism has increased in the last few years. Since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers. But, not all the news is bad for civilians. Although people are nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from political conflict, the global murder rate has gone down a little, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Wasfia has spent her life helping others learn about human rights. She worked on many projects in her country to teach and train women and girls. But when these projects stopped, the women and girls often had nothing. Wasfia thought Bangladesh needed to help itself. She loves climbing mountains and wanted to help women more. She began climbing when she was helping people in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, there are not many mountains. Now, people in Bangladesh and around the world are paying attention to her work.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified: Many people think that developing countries are in a bad situation. They think there is a lot of poverty, and dictators are in power, with no hope for change. But this is not true. Big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have more money now and are not poor anymore. Also, six million fewer children die each year from sickness. Millions more girls can go to school, and many people have clean water to drink.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Many managers like to give one good comment, then a bad comment, and then one more good comment. This way, they try to make the bad feedback seem nicer. But if they do this all the time, workers might think the good comments are not real, just a way to make bad comments look better. Good feedback should be real and help workers continue doing a good job.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified: I am part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary robots from movies. Instead, think about what is happening today: machines used by the military, like drones and gun turrets, are already used to kill with little help from people. The next step is machines that can choose on their own who to kill, called 'murderbots'. I believe this is very wrong and dangerous for people. We need to be very careful about what we let machines do.

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
simplified: Many people are learning English, more than any other language. English is used in most countries. But, Chinese has the most people who speak it from birth. There is not a big link between the number of people born speaking a language and the number of people learning it. But, there is a better link between how many people learn a language and how many countries use it.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified: Your manager stops you and says she wants to talk about how you worked on the recent project. You worry all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go to her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying you did a good job on the project. You wonder if this is part of the 'feedback sandwich' where someone first says something nice, then tells you the real problem, and finally says something nice again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified: Born in the USA is a rock music album that is fun to listen to and makes you want to move. However, the songs also have deep feelings. The music sounds lively, but there are stories about the problems people face with the American dream. Many of the songs talk about how hard-working people feel sad and angry when life is difficult, and they don’t get rich or famous. For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town who remember being young and feeling like they could do anything. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man whose life gets worse when he loses his job. You can imagine that the singer is thinking about real people he knew and how his own life could have been if he had not become famous. This album shows how special and talented the singer, known as the Boss, is.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified: Lewis wants the number of protected places in the ocean to go up from 3% to 10%. He hopes this will help fix the damage people have caused, like too much fishing, polluting, and throwing trash. Lewis has seen this damage himself on his trips. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water got too warm. He has also seen areas in the Red Sea that are empty of life and covered with plastic. Pugh thinks nature can heal itself if we give it space, but we need to act soon. If we do not take care of the oceans now, we might have a big problem that we cannot solve later.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified: Terrie Sharp is a very famous writer. She won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times because she writes great stories. She grew up in a part of Glasgow where there was a lot of crime. Her childhood taught her how to be quiet, stay safe, and open car doors with a knife. But she only used these skills for writing her books. Now, she talks more and is often on TV shows like Police Today and goes to writing events in the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? In his book 'Enlightenment Now,' Steven Pinker talks about human life and has good news. We are living longer, healthier, and happier lives. Pinker says the problem is that people fight against thinking and science. When people in the news use fear and make others not trust each other, it can hurt important things like democracy and countries working together.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In old horror movies, when people were very scared or in danger, it was hard or not possible to call someone for help or to call the police. Mobile phones today make this situation less believable. What can they do to keep the story exciting? No phone signal! If you are the hero in a horror movie, it's almost sure that at an important moment, just when you really need to call for help, your phone will not work. Or your phone battery will die when you are trying to call. Or both things will happen.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their best banana, called Big Mike, was dying. Now, the same problem is happening to the banana that came after Big Mike, called the Cavendish. Big Mike was very popular because it was sweet, had a thick skin, and was easy to move. A company named United Fruit grew and sold bananas in South America. They grew lots of bananas by making new plants from old plants, not seeds, and put them very close together in big fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom. They use it to catch food, not to attack people. Only 25 types of spiders have venom that can really hurt humans. Spider bites can hurt, but they usually do not kill people. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider is famous, but no one has died from it since a special medicine, called anti-venom, was made in 1981. Be careful with spiders like tarantulas. If you scare them, they can throw tiny, itchy hairs at you. These hairs can get into your skin or eyes and feel bad.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified: This idea in horror movies was very common in the late 1900s. The movie starts with a group of teenagers having fun. In the end, everyone is dead except for one girl. At first, the girl is nice, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes very tough and smart. The last girl almost always survives.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To understand where our ability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from animal brains. It's not just about brain size; what's important are the other things our brains can do and when and why they changed this way. There are not many physical clues for this. Things left by our ancestors don't show what kind of speech they could make. But, in the remains of early humans, we can see the development of the mouth, throat, and tongue. About 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to talk.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, tells us that girls should like arts and humanities more and should let boys do maths and physics. Also, there are not many women in science jobs for children to see. Many cartoons and stories show the crazy scientist, smart inventor, or brave astronaut as a man. People also wrongly think that scientists are nerds, have bad social skills, or that their work is lonely and cut off from the world. These are not true, but they can make girls think that they don't belong in science and that it is not a good job for them. If girls saw more female role models in science, they would feel more confident and feel that they belong in those subjects.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified: The Scallion is a newspaper made by students. It comes out every week and is free. Around 10,000 students read it. The paper is important for fun, learning about culture, and getting work experience. Printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. Also, some students cannot get the paper easily because they have to go to the university to get it. Many copies of the newspaper are just thrown away and become trash on campus.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, every year about 12 out of 100 workers leave their jobs. This might not seem high at first, but usually, only 7 out of 100 workers leave their jobs in other companies like ours. The main goal of this report is to find out why employees are interested in their work and to give ideas to make work better for employees and help them stay with us longer.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: I agree with the speaker. I think if we are more connected, we might feel more alone. For people of my age, it is not a big problem. We lived without technology for a long time. We know how to be alone and that being alone is fine. But young people under 20 are different. They are always talking to others, so they never feel alone. They might not learn to enjoy being by themselves. Also, they learn to talk by sending messages that they can change. This means they might not learn how to talk face-to-face with someone right in front of them.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Don't always say something bad after saying something good. If you do this too much, people might not care about the good things you say. Sometimes, just say something nice and don't add anything bad. Try to keep good and bad comments separate.

original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can give you new ideas about things you didn't know you were thinking about. Many people have dreams like flying, falling, losing their teeth, or being without clothes in public. These dreams might have similar meanings for most people. However, to know what they mean for you, you should think about the events and feelings in your own life.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: A very interesting example of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, about 35,000 wild dogs live on the streets. Some of these dogs were born on the streets, while others used to be pets that their owners left behind. Some dogs live by themselves, and others stay in groups. In 2010, scientists looked at these dogs and saw that they have gotten very good at living in the city. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs even seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified: Wonder is the first book by RJ Palacio, who is from New York. On her website, she says she got the idea for the book after she saw a girl with a different-looking face on the street one day. Wonder has sold many copies in the United States and has won some awards. Many schools are using this book to talk about bullying, friendship, and being different. A movie is being made from the book, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio will write next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified: Chloe has two pet rats named Zena and Roxy. She knows that rats are not common pets and often explains to people that they are not dirty. She believes rats can be great pets if they are cared for properly. Chloe understands why people might not like rats. She also didn't like them until her friend Martin showed her his rats. She saw that they were friendly and smart. Last year, when Martin's rat had babies, Chloe decided she wanted to have two of them.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons are hurt or killed in car accidents, and some are electrocuted when they play with electric wires. Baboons are an endangered species, which means there are not many left, and we need to protect them. To help them and reduce problems between people and baboons, the city council has hired a group called Baboon Monitors. These monitors have a job to scare baboons away from the city or catch them and let them go back into the wild. This plan has worked a little, but it is still difficult to keep baboons away from the city once they know they can find easy food there.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big IT company that is based in the United States, but I do all my work from home online. This means I don't have to spend time traveling to work or talking with colleagues. I work on different projects, and this flexible schedule is very helpful for me. I can take breaks, like going to my children's school events or going to the dentist. However, the bad part is that I often work late into the evening because I don't have set office hours, and sometimes I even miss dinner to complete a job.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti was still popular. But there was also a lot more street art. Some artists wanted to share their ideas about politics. They made art to make people think about war and unfair treatment. Other artists just wanted to make beautiful pictures. In South America, many street artists painted in poor places. They added color and beauty to the grey city walls.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: Every day, people see many ads on social media, in magazines, and in store displays telling them to buy things. In the UK, people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever. Online shopping makes it easy for them to buy things without a second thought. Big brands sell clothes so cheaply that people often wear them only a few times before throwing them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the dust in the distance, created by the car going up to the Big House. The horses moved their tails to shoo away flies, not caring that their owner was visiting for the first time in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came out here when he had to, and Sam liked it that way. The less he saw his boss, the longer he could keep his job. Mr. Carter wiped the sweat from his neck. The wet spots on his shirt looked like shapes on a map. His skin was starting to get red in the June sun. Otherwise, he had the pale skin of a man who made money while others worked.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: Many people living in Berlin, Germany said that shooting pigs was too mean, and there were strong disagreements between hunters and people who care about animals. Because of these complaints, the city council decided to find a kinder way to deal with the pigs. Instead of shooting them, they put up fences and made it against the law to feed the pigs. We will see if this plan works, but it might not solve the problem because warmer winters have caused there to be more pigs than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
simplified: Suzanne Collins got a big idea for her Hunger Games book from her love of old Greek stories. As a child, she really liked the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens is controlled by Crete, but the people of Athens fight against Crete. As a result, King Minos of Crete makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls every year to Crete. These young people are put into a maze where a monster called the Minotaur eats them. But one young man, Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne thinks of Katniss Everdeen as a future version of Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. simplified: Lewis wants the number of protected areas in the ocean to grow from 3 percent to 10 percent. simplified: Are things getting worse every day? Is it impossible to make progress? In his book 'Enlightenment Now,' Steven Pinker looks at how humans have improved and finds good news. original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. simplified: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most important type of banana, called the Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying out. United Fruit, a major company in South America, found a way to grow a lot of these bananas quickly. They did this by cloning, which means they made new plants from parts of old ones instead of using seeds, and they grew them close together in fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom that helps them catch and eat their prey, not to hurt people. In fact, only 25 types of spiders have venom that can be dangerous to humans. While spider bites can hurt, they usually aren't deadly. For example, there have been no deaths from the Sydney funnel-web spider in Australia since they made a special medicine in 1981. However, be careful around hairy spiders like tarantulas. When they feel threatened, they protect themselves by releasing tiny hairs. These hairs can get stuck in the skin or eyes and are very irritating.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To understand where our ability for complex language comes from, we need to look at how our brains are different from those of other animals. It's not just about brain size; we need to consider what our brains can do, and when and why they developed those abilities. There are not many physical clues to help us; objects left by our ancestors don’t show us what kind of speech they used. However, we can learn something from the remains of early humans. We can see how their mouth, throat, and tongue developed. Around 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only guess if early humans communicated with simpler sounds.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Our society, not nature, often suggests that girls should like subjects like arts and humanities, while boys should focus on maths and physics. Also, there are not many female role models in science for young people to look up to. Many cartoons and stories show scientists, inventors, or astronauts as men. Unfortunately, people often think scientists are nerdy, have poor social skills, or work alone, which is not true. These are false ideas often shown by the media, but they can make girls feel like they don't fit in with scientists and see science as an unattractive career choice. If girls saw more women succeeding in science, it would help them feel more confident and believe they belong in those subjects.
